trial_identification.studytitle: The PREDICT Study- a Registry in Critically Ill Patients to Determine Predictors of Disability Free Survival
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The PREDICT Study- a Registry in Critically Ill Patients to Determine Predictors of Disability Free Survival

primaryOutcome.outcome: Development of a risk-prediction model for disability-free survival in high risk patients (after > 24 hours of mechanical ventilation)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Health related quality of life (HRQOL) measured with EQ5D before ICU (retrospective survey) and at 6 months (prospective survey)
Retrospective EQ5D to measure pre ICU health status
Physical activity at 3 and 6 months- IADL
Cognitive function at 3 and 6 months- MOCA blind
Anxiety and depression at 3 and 6 months will be assessed with the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) and the Impact of Event Scale (IES-R)
Return to work at 3 and 6 months
Retrospective WHODAS to measure pre ICU disability and work status

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - ICU patients who have been mechanically ventilated for over 24 hours
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- Patients aged less than 18 years old
- A Proven or suspected acute primary brain process that is likely to result in global impairment of conscious level or cognition (e.g. TBI, SAH, stroke or hypoxic brain injury after cardiac arrest)
- Second or subsequent admission to ICU during a single hospital admission
- Death is deemed imminent and inevitable
- Participants who do not speak English

recruitment.hospital: Australian New Zealand Intensive Care Reseearch Centre - Melbourne

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Australian and New Zealand Intensive Care Research Centre

othercollaborator.othercollaboratorname: National Health and Medical Research Council, Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary: As mortality from critical illness has reduced, the importance of measuring disabilities (cognitive, functional and psychological) in surviving critically ill patients has become more important. Currently, the causes, long-term effects and frequency of disabilities in patients surviving ICU in Australia are unknown. In the US and UK, studies have been undertaken to assess the effects of specific long-term outcomes, such as functional disability and depression, which found long-term disabilities were much higher than baselines (pre-illness function) and ongoing at five years after ICU discharge. In order to improve quality of life of ICU survivors and ensure that medical specialists apply appropriate interventions to reduce the cost of these surviving patients on the community, the PREDICT management committee proposes the introduction of a patient-reported outcomes registry.
